文献ID: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_012_chunk1
证据片段: Two varieties of Zircaloy-2, with different second phase particle (SPP) size distributions and different corrosion resistance, were oxidized in a steam autoclave.

文献ID: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_012_chunk1
证据片段: Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) of large thin-foil cross-sections of the oxide and the adjacent metal shows an undulating metal/oxide interface in both materials with a periodicity of slightly less than 1 $\mu \mathsf { m }$ and an amplitude of around $1 0 0 \mathsf { n m }$

证据片段: APT analysis was performed with an Imago LEAP 3000X HR instrument in laser mode, using a specimen temperature of $^ { 7 0 \mathrm { K } }$ , laser pulse frequency of $2 0 0 \mathrm { k H z }$ and laser pulse energy of $0 . 5 \mathrm { n J }$

文献ID: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_012_chunk3
证据片段: STEM ADF images of the undulating metal/oxide interface of Materials A and B with an oxide thickness of 1 µm.

文献ID: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_012_chunk3
证据片段: Bright-field TEM image of an un-oxidized sample of Material A showing that the original surface before oxidation is straight. The natural oxide is only 50 nm thick.

文献ID: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_012_chunk4
证据片段: This SPP is naturally not oxidized, since the oxidation front has not yet reached it.

文献ID: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_012_chunk4
证据片段: The oxygen content decreases significantly in the particle compared to the surrounding oxide, indicating that it is not oxidized.

文献ID: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_012_chunk5
证据片段: the material with the largest amount of particles, Material A, also has the largest number of cracks (Fig. 3). The particles in Material B are fewer but also larger. Since there are fewer cracks in this material it seems that the number density of particles is a more important parameter than the particle size when it comes to crack formation.

证据片段: FIG. 10—Zr and O TEM EDX line scan showing an indication of a 200 nm thick layer of sub-oxide at the metal/oxide interface of Material $B$ with an oxide thickness of 1 µm.

文献ID: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_012_chunk5
证据片段: The oxygen content in the adjacent bulk oxide was measured to slightly less than the 67 at. $\%$ that would be expected for zirconia, ${ \bf Z } \mathrm { r } { \bf O } _ { 2 }$

文献ID: STP1529-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_16th Volume_012_chunk5
证据片段: After the step a smooth diffusion profile into the metal is found. As the APT investigation only runs $5 0 ~ \mathrm { n m }$ into the metal, the oxygen content is still above 10 at. $\%$ when the concentration profile ends
